definitions.definition: to have to pay somebody for something that you have already received or return money that you have borrowed
definitions.sensetop: owe somebody somethingowe somethingowe something to somebodyowe something to somebody for somethingowe somebody something for something

examples.text: She still owes her father £3 000.
I'm still owed three days' leave.
He **owes** more **money** than he can afford to pay.
Exactly how much do we owe?
She still owes £3 000 to her father.
The country owes billions of dollars to foreign creditors.
Most hospitals owe money to pharmaceutical companies for medicines and equipment.
examples.contextForm: owe something to somebody for something

examples.text: How much do I owe you for the groceries?

definitions.definition: to feel that you ought to do something for somebody or give them something, especially because they have done something for you
definitions.sensetop: owe something to somebodyowe somebody something

examples.text: I **owe a debt of gratitude** to all my family.
You **owe it to** your staff to be honest with them.
I **owe a duty** to my family.
You owe me a favour!
Thanks for sticking up for me—I **owe you one** *(= I owe you a favour)*.
I think you **owe** us **an explanation**.
I think we're **owed an apology**.

definitions.definition: to exist or be successful because of the help or influence of somebody/something
definitions.sensetop: owe something to somebody/somethingowe somebody something

examples.text: He owes his success to hard work.
The play owes much to French tragedy.
I owe everything to him.
The town **owes its existence** to the minerals that lie below the mountains.
I owe him everything.
I knew that I owed the surgeon my life.

definitions.definition: to have to obey and support somebody who is in a position of authority or power

examples.text: All serfs owed allegiance to a lord.

wordOrigin: Old English āgan ‘own, have it as an obligation’, of Germanic origin; from an Indo-European root shared by Sanskrit īs ‘possess, own’.
